 At the end of the 16th century, the bishops of the established Church of England pushed through laws which called for banishment of those opposed to its teachings and in 1604 at the Hampton Court Conference, King James I confirmed that measures would would be taken to make everyone conform to the Anglican Church. As a result, more than 300 clergymen were expelled from their livings for non-compliance.
 
 Some of these non-conformist congregations (or religious separatists) seeking religious freedom, were the nucleus of permanent English settlements in America - as opposed to mere economic adventurers grabbing land on which to set up trading operations.
 
 If we take the so-called Pilgrim Fathers on the Mayflower as a sample of early British immigrants to America, what qualifies them for the description of "nutters" or "raving loons" ? 
 
 James.
Phunting

The vast majority of early emigration from England and Scotland was initially for entirely economic reasons. Trading Companies set up colonies in order to return profit. Whilst of course we were also undergoing huge religious upheaval, the 'pilgrim fathers', commonly seen as in the group leaving fleeing 'persecution', did not arrive in the New World until 1620. This is considerably after the first successful commercial efforts of Jamestown (sponsored by the Virginia Company).
 
 Now I agree that those dissatisfied with recent changes of the Church of England and Scotland were more likely to be amongst those happy to set up a new life in the colonies, the myth that the early settling of America was a religious and not primarily economic one is a severe distortion.

 The Pilgrims who established the Plymouth colony were not seeking gold or hoping to make a fortune. They wanted to build a Christian commonwealth. They belonged to the most uncompromising sect of Puritans (called Separatists) who had broken all connection with the Church of England. And they sought religious freedom abroad - first in Holland and afterwards in America. King James would not promise outright toleration if they set up a colony, but he did agree to leave them alone.
 
 This puritan strain of religious sentiment is historically important in the development of American culture.

The Pilgrims who established the Plymouth colony were not seeking gold or hoping to make a fortune. They wanted to build a Christian commonwealth. They belonged to the most uncompromising sect of Puritans (called Separatists) who had broken all connection with the Church of England.
All agreed.
 
 
 
And they sought religious freedom abroad - first in Holland and afterwards in America. King James would not promise outright toleration if they set up a colony, but he did agree to leave them alone.
But here I don't. Yes, this is indeed what they claimed. They wanted freedom from persecution of their beliefs. Their beliefs mainly being that anything that smacked of popery should be destroyed. After James VI/I's ascension to the throne they realized the good old days of gallivanting round the country burning Catholics were over, so packed up their things and went.
 
 OK, not quite, I'll admit that James' crack down on separatism was overly harsh and the final straw to prompt the move. However the Separatist movement was essentially an objection to what they saw as continuing popery both officially and unofficially from the Crown; therefore it does seem that they were fleeing the idea that Catholics should be allowed freedom every bit as much as they were fleeing their own persecution.
 
 
This puritan strain of religious sentiment is historically important in the development of American culture. 
Well quite.
 
 
 
I agree that the economic history of the United States, which as far as English commerce was concerned began at the time of Walter Raleigh (in the 1580s), is to some extent a tale of exploitation of resources and land grabbing. But that is a different topic from the narrow study of American cultural transformations. 
I would say the two are intrinsically linked. Take slavery for example, culturally an aspect of massive import in America, yet something whose roots are firmly grounded in the economic aspect to America's colonization.
 
 
 To claim that Brits moved to America for economic reasons is quite comical. 
 A move to America was hardly a step up economically. I'm sure different Brits had different goals though and will concede. 
 Mexicans "Illegally immigrating" to America, bypassing the subscribed method of immigration I view as a step toward anarchy. The beginning of the downfall of Democracy.
Oh really? Well firstly I wasn't saying they moved for the same economic reasons as Mexicans, just that economic interests were behind America's colonization. 
 
 That said, it's not untrue that 'a step up economically' as you say was a pretty major factor. Let's look at who moved there: it was almost entirely the middle and working classes, those who saw the chance for social mobility outside the rigid structures of the British class systems. The yeomen saw it as a way to become the landed gentry themselves, to set themselves up as a new aristocracy without having to bow to the established one. The labourers saw it as an opportunity to advance their lot in life; the vast majority were young single men with little to loose by leaving their former lives behind. Why else would someone leave everything they knew behind? Why else would next to no immigrants be from the upper classes and aristocracy? It was because the move to the colonies was primarily seen as an opportunity for economic and social advancement.
James

All agreed.
 But here I don't. Yes, this is indeed what they claimed. They wanted freedom from persecution of their beliefs. Their beliefs mainly being that anything that smacked of popery should be destroyed. After James VI/I's ascension to the throne they realized the good old days of gallivanting round the country burning Catholics were over, so packed up their things and went.

 This is an oversimplification. Yes, the Puritans were anti-catholic, but anti-catholicism had been a government policy since the accession of Elizabeth in the middle of the 16th century. There were theological differences between the Separatists of the 17th century and the established church, and disagreement about its governance. Congregationalism is at odds with both the authority of bishops and the role of the sovereign as "supreme governor" of the Church of England. 
 
I would say the two are intrinsically linked. Take slavery for example, culturally an aspect of massive import in America, yet something whose roots are firmly grounded in the economic aspect to America's colonization.

 The institution of slavery in the United States is obviously linked with its economic development. But the cultural contribution that slaves made to American society before their emancipation tended to be indirect and passive. Generally speaking, free men and women (actively) shape the intellectual, religious, and artistic history of a culture. 
 
 James.

Arguments about about the pros and cons of immigration - leaving aside the problem of its legality - seldom address the question of a ceiling figure. How many people can be admitted and for how long before the door should be closed with a "Sorry, full up" sign on it? Worries about overpopulation don't seem to get noticed much. 
 
 Immigrants occupying the lowest rung on the social ladder tend to have more children than the average indigenous family. After a generation or two, when the incomers have had time to get a better education, prosper, and move up the income scale, the demographics usually settle back to the mean (or norm). The pressure on space and resources eases off.
 
 But this assumes that the past history of immigration is a reliable guide to the future, and that an economy will keep expanding and mopping up surplus labour indefinitely. If it does not, then a so-called under-class of immigrants without prospects of social mobility is likely to continue to multiply, accumulate grievances, and become further estranged from the host nation. 
 
 America is such a vast country that (on the face of it) overpopulation seems a very long way off. But presumably there is a limit to the number of immigrants that even the United States can be expected to absorb without the standard of living taking a severe knock.

 Allow me to skewer your point:
 
 
 Illegal Immigrants' Cost to Government Studied 
 
 By Mary Fitzgerald
 Washington Post Staff Writer
 
 
 A report that found that illegal immigrants in the United States cost the federal government more than $10 billion a year -- a sum it estimated would almost triple if they were given amnesty -- has drawn criticism from immigration advocacy groups.
 
 For its report, the Center for Immigration Studies, a Washington-based group that advocates tougher immigration policies, used Census Bureau figures to compare the revenue that illegal immigrants contribute through taxes with the cost of government services they use.
 
 "Households headed by illegal aliens imposed more than $26.3 billion in costs on the federal government in 2002 and paid only $16 billion in taxes, creating a net fiscal deficit of $10.4 billion, or $2,700 per illegal household," said Steven A. Camarota, author of the study.
 
 The costs outlined in the report include government services such as Medicaid, medical treatment for the uninsured, food assistance programs, the federal prison and court systems, and federal aid to schools.
 
 The study acknowledged that, on average, the costs that illegal-immigrant households bear on the federal government are less than half that of other households, and that many of those costs relate to their U.S.-born children. It also pointed out that tax payments by illegal-immigrant households constitute one-fourth those of other households because of low-income jobs.
 
 "With nearly two-thirds of illegal aliens lacking a high school degree, the primary reason they create a fiscal deficit is their low education levels and resulting low incomes and tax payments, not their legal status or heavy use of most social services," Camarota said.
 
 The report estimates that granting legal status to illegal immigrants would dramatically increase their cost, causing the net fiscal deficit to rise to nearly $29 billion because, the author argues, unskilled immigrants would have access to more government services while continuing to make modest tax payments.
 
 Camarota concluded in his report that the fiscal impact could be lessened only by stringently enforcing immigration laws, a view that drew criticism from some immigration specialists and advocacy groups that also accused him of not coming up with constructive recommendations.
James

I'm against borders. Breaking laws regarding them I see as trivial.

 I can't believe you wouldn't qualify this statement by saying you're in favour of selecting immigrants by health, education, employability, and so on.
 
 If the United States were to declare an open border both by land and ocean and with no restrictions at all, many millions of people would flock there. I'd be on the first plane myself. 
 
 A massive uncontrolled influx of immigrants could be a social and cultural fiasco for America, and tantamount to economic suicide.
 
 James.

Zardoz

sinjin,
 
 I'm against borders. Breaking laws regarding them I see as trivial.
 
 Agreed.
 
 Borders are nothiing more than artificial constructs (lines) drawn on another artificial construct (a map).

 
 Ummm...
 Nearly everything is an artificial construct.
 
 Including your right to possess things and not be pummelled by Santa's mighty boots of Doom. As well as 'Santas' right not to have his family retaliated against by your family.
 
 Borders are created for many psychological reasons...and are an extension on the body-space issues most people seem to have hardwired in.
 It's a way of keeping the all pervasive 'others' out and away.
 And there will ALWAYS be 'others' because humans are hardwired to only be able to care for some small number of people (often refered to as 'us').
 
 So, if you cross the artificial border on my property, my territorial instincts will go off and I'll sick trained attack dogs on you...probably shoot you too. And use a throw down weapon to get the 'artificially created laws' to dismiss the bogus charges of murder.
 
 
 Curiosity kills the cat for a reason.
sinjin

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schengen_Agreement#Travel_without_internal_border_controls
 
 Recent relaxation of border controls in Europe.
sinjin

So, if you cross the artificial border on my property, my territorial instincts will go off and I'll sick trained attack dogs on you...probably shoot you too. And use a throw down weapon to get the 'artificially created laws' to dismiss the bogus charges of murder.

 
 Issues of private property and international borders are not especially parallel to my mind.
bhbcu64

sinjin,
 
 Recent relaxation of border controls in Europe.
 
 Fascinating, isn't it, that a European can travel from Prague to Lisbon without "papers", but there are those who would stop someone who wanted to go from Juarez to El Paso.;)
Zardoz

Issues of private property and international borders are not especially parallel to my mind.

 
 Has nothing to do with 'private property' as much as it does to ingrained levels of xenophobia and a strong desire to keep the 'other' away from yourself.
 
 The further removed one is from another, the more strange and alien they become.
 
 You'd probably have less of a problem with those near you infringing on your borders than you would have someone from the other side of the world.
 
 Borders...ironically, exist mostly along cultural lines and other natural demarcations.
 
 
 As to yourself, not all humans are created the same.
 My wife's a clinical narcassist but, has no 'personal space' at all.
 You'll also find that many cosmopolitan style people have less issues with these borders and, like you have little problems dismissing them however this doesn't translate to all. Much like the ingrained religion most possess. Just because a few 'see the light' and dismiss them as nonsense doesn't mean the majority will fallow along.
 
 Look at the last posters implications on travel.
 One will also note that Europeans are more cosmopolitan that we here in America. They should also note that the borders are relatively close to the capitals of the countries that deal with these rules.
 D.C. is quite a bit away from the Mexican border. Not quite 'in touch' with the realities or practicalities of those as they pass down laws. Thus the recent criticism on how these laws will slow down business traffic, costing money and time.
 I think it quite funny the issuing of decrees now requiring passports for citizens to cross the border to Canada and Mexico...when those borders are quite porous.
 Who they going to stop?
 Terrorists, drug smugglers, coyotes and gang-bangers?
 Not in a million years with things being the way they are.
 What's next to fix them?
 Barbed wire and mines...*cough*iron curtain*cough* ...sweeeeet.
 
 
 But, in conclusion, most things originate on the psychological level is what I'm saying. Are adapted with changes in culture and technology.
 The borders of France were quite far away from the capital, relatively speaking, when cars were limited or non-existant.
 The only places where borders are really ignored are in regions where tribal people have a history of traveling back and forth across them regardless of what an outside government wishes.
Taxi Rob

Free movement between nations like we enjoy presently between States.

 
 The States are more even in terms of laws and living conditions than other nations. Let me put it to another issue: The "NAU" or "SPP." I'll tell you what sinjin, I'd be fine with that if we got Canadian style healthcare out of the deal, and Mexico did too. Nations must be on equal terms for this to work or there would be massive population shifts that would bankrupt local governments, which is why Europe is taking so long to integrate on purpose. After the collapse of the Iron Curtain, the West had a hard time finding work for all the new Eastern Bloc immigrants. Quotas were necessary, and Western investors needed time to rebuild the economy of the East. The massive flow stopped when equilibrium was achieved. 
 
 We can't have half the population of Mexico come running across the plains willy-nilly. There need to be jobs and infrastructure to support them, but our own jobs are leaving, and our own infrastructure is failing. Sure they could help us rebuild it for less, but where will displaced American laborers go? Don't you think we should help our brother before we worry about our neighbor? We can't retrain our unskilled workforce to do much else, they are mostly people who aren't cut out for academia for myriad reasons. They have no less value in our society, but bringing in replacements to benefit the bottom lines of corporations makes them a new burden with a higher cost of living. (We could make cigarette smoking and cursing into felonies and imprison them all, which is the way we are headed.)
 
 Slighly off topic: to not learn the lesson the Europeans did about immigration is to not learn the lesson the Russians did about internal terrorism. Which is funny since Condi Rice claims she learned everything she knows from the Cold War; obviously she slept through the closing credits. Sorry, I had to get that in there.

post_info.post_title: Huh? Sounds nice but apples and oranges

Taxi Rob

Borders are nothing more than artificial constructs.
 
 Choice is a set of intersecting needs and abilities. You can plot them on a graph and get a shape that you can call what you will. Take choice out of your equations, because it is an unknown set of integers, and will invariably lead to an incorrect solution. 
 
 "Choosing" to cross the border illegally is based on the need for resources and the ability to get them. One could just as easily "choose" to run for office in one's own homeland and effect positive change, could they not? One could also "choose" to revolt against their government in open combat to secure their own liberty, yes? 
 
 People tend to take the path of least resistance. How would America look today if we had always taken the path of least resistance? In some ways better, in some ways worse, but our "choices" as a nation weren't any more real than yours or mine today. 
 
 Our only real choices are between thinking about the future or not, thinking about our fellow man or not, and thinking about our own best interest or not. These are just aspects of a larger process and are not choices in themselves. If you start to see your self as a set of intersecting needs and abilities, you realize that so is everyone else. Then you get the big picture-in HiDef.
CUNxTime

One difference between the immigrants of yesteryear and many of the illegals of today are that the immigrants of the early 1900's and earlier were coming here to stay. They had a reason to work hard to make the system better and improve the country for their children and their children's children.
 An extremely large percentage of those coming illegally today are coming here to earn enough money to send back to their country so they can buy land and a house and start a business etc... The problem with that is they have no reason to reinvest in the country and they have no stake in the future of the country which leads to a scorched earth policy. If people were serious about improving there lot via improving the country, we probably wouldn't even be having this discussion...
